messages.content: This is an LLM Agent for optimization problems

A company is deciding where to promote their product. Some options include z-tube, soorchle engine, and wassa advertisements. The cost for each option and the number of viewers they each attract is given. On z-tube, each ad costs $1000 and attracts 400,000 viewers. On soorchle, each ad costs $200 and attracts 5,000 viewers. On wassa, each ad costs $100 and attracts 3,000 viewers. Soorchle limits the number of advertisements from a single company to fifteen. Moreover, in order to balance the advertising among the three types of media, at most a third of the total number of advertisements should occur on wassa. And at least 5% should occur on z-tube. The weekly advertising budget is $10000. How many advertisements should be run in each of the three types of media to maximize the total audience?

{"background": "A company is deciding where to promote their product with options including z-tube, soorchle engine, and wassa advertisements.", "constraints": [ "Number of z-tube ads is an integer", "Number of soorchle ads is an integer", "Number of wassa ads is an integer", "Number of z-tube ads is non-negative", "Number of soorchle ads is non-negative", "Number of wassa ads is non-negative", "Total spending on z-tube ads does not exceed Budget", "Total spending on soorchle ads does not exceed Budget", "Total spending on wassa ads does not exceed Budget", "The sum of spending on z-tube, soorchle, and wassa ads does not exceed Budget", "Number of soorchle ads is at most MaxAdsSoorchle", "Number of wassa ads is at most MaxPropWassa times the total number of ads", "Number of z-tube ads is at least MinPropZtube times the total number of ads" ], "objective": "Maximize the total number of viewers from ads across all platforms", "parameters": [ { "definition": "Cost of an advertisement on z-tube", "symbol": "CostZtube", "value": 1000, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Number of viewers attracted by an advertisement on z-tube", "symbol": "ViewersZtube", "value": 400000, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Cost of an advertisement on soorchle", "symbol": "CostSoorchle", "value": 200, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Number of viewers attracted by an advertisement on soorchle", "symbol": "ViewersSoorchle", "value": 5000, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Cost of an advertisement on wassa", "symbol": "CostWassa", "value": 100, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Number of viewers attracted by an advertisement on wassa", "symbol": "ViewersWassa", "value": 3000, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Maximum number of advertisements allowed on soorchle", "symbol": "MaxAdsSoorchle", "value": 15, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Maximum proportion of the total number of advertisements that should occur on wassa", "symbol": "MaxPropWassa", "value": 0.33, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Minimum proportion of the total number of advertisements that should occur on z-tube", "symbol": "MinPropZtube", "value": 0.05, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Weekly advertising budget", "symbol": "Budget", "value": 10000, "shape": [] } ] }

A chair produced by Elm Furniture yields a profit of $43, while every dresser yields a $52 profit. Each week, 17 gallons of stain and 11 lengths of oak wood are available. Each chair requires 1.4 gallons of stain and 2 lengths of oak wood, while each dresser requires 1.1 gallons of stain and 3 lengths of oak wood. Determine the maximum profit.

{ "background": "Elm Furniture produces chairs and dressers, generating profit from each.", "constraints": [ "Number of chairs is an integer", "Number of dressers is an integer", "Number of chairs is non-negative", "Number of dressers is non-negative", "Total stain used for chairs and dressers cannot exceed TotalStain gallons per week", "Total oak wood used for chairs and dressers cannot exceed TotalOak lengths per week", "Each chair requires StainPerChair gallons of stain", "Each dresser requires StainPerDresser gallons of stain", "Each chair requires OakPerChair lengths of oak wood", "Each dresser requires OakPerDresser lengths of oak wood" ], "objective": "Maximize the total profit from chairs and dressers", "parameters": [ { "definition": "Profit for each chair produced", "symbol": "ProfitChair", "value": 43, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Profit for each dresser produced", "symbol": "ProfitDresser", "value": 52, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Total gallons of stain available per week", "symbol": "TotalStain", "value": 17, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Total lengths of oak wood available per week", "symbol": "TotalOak", "value": 11, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Amount of stain required for one chair", "symbol": "StainPerChair", "value": 1.4, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Amount of oak wood required for one chair", "symbol": "OakPerChair", "value": 2, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Amount of stain required for one dresser", "symbol": "StainPerDresser", "value": 1.1, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Amount of oak wood required for one dresser", "symbol": "OakPerDresser", "value": 3, "shape": [] } ] }

A farmer wants to mix his animal feeds, Feed A and Feed B, in such a way that the mixture will contain a minimum of 30 units of protein and 50 units of fat. Feed A costs $100 per kilogram and contains 10 units of protein and 8 units of fat. Feed B costs $80 per kilogram and contains 7 units of protein and 15 units of fat. Determine the minimum cost of the mixture.

{ "background": "A farmer wants to mix two types of animal feeds, Feed A and Feed B, to meet the minimum requirements of protein and fat at the minimum cost.", "constraints": [ "Amount of Feed A is non-negative", "Amount of Feed B is non-negative", "The mixture must contain at least MinProtein units of protein", "The mixture must contain at least MinFat units of fat" ], "objective": "Minimize the total cost of the mixture", "parameters": [ { "definition": "Cost per kilogram for Feed A", "symbol": "CostA", "value": 100, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Cost per kilogram for Feed B", "symbol": "CostB", "value": 80, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Protein content per kilogram of Feed A", "symbol": "ProteinA", "value": 10, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Protein content per kilogram of Feed B", "symbol": "ProteinB", "value": 7, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Fat content per kilogram of Feed A", "symbol": "FatA", "value": 8, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Fat content per kilogram of Feed B", "symbol": "FatB", "value": 15, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Minimum required units of protein in the feed mixture", "symbol": "MinProtein", "value": 30, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Minimum required units of fat in the feed mixture", "symbol": "MinFat", "value": 50, "shape": [] } ] }

An artisan makes two types of terracotta jars: a thin jar and a stubby jar. Each thin jar requires 50 minutes of shaping time and 90 minutes of baking time. Each stubby jar requires 30 minutes of shaping time and 150 minutes of baking time. Per week, there are 3000 minutes available for shaping and 4000 minutes available for baking. The profit per thin jar is $5 and the profit per stubby jar is $9. How many jars of each type should the artisan make to maximize profit?

{ "background": "An artisan makes two types of terracotta jars: a thin jar and a stubby jar.", "constraints": [ "Number of thin jars is an integer", "Number of stubby jars is an integer", "Number of thin jars is non-negative", "Number of stubby jars is non-negative", "Total shaping time for thin and stubby jars cannot exceed TotalShapingTime minutes per week", "Total baking time for thin and stubby jars cannot exceed TotalBakingTime minutes per week" ], "objective": "Maximize the artisan's weekly profit from the jars", "parameters": [ { "definition": "Minutes required to shape one thin jar", "symbol": "ThinShapingTime", "value": 50, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Minutes required to bake one thin jar", "symbol": "ThinBakingTime", "value": 90, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Minutes required to shape one stubby jar", "symbol": "StubbyShapingTime", "value": 30, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Minutes required to bake one stubby jar", "symbol": "StubbyBakingTime", "value": 150, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Total available shaping minutes per week", "symbol": "TotalShapingTime", "value": 3000, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Total available baking minutes per week", "symbol": "TotalBakingTime", "value": 4000, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Profit per thin jar", "symbol": "ProfitThin", "value": 5, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Profit per stubby jar", "symbol": "ProfitStubby", "value": 9, "shape": [] } ] }

A grocery store wants to liquidate its stock of 10 apples, 20 bananas, and 80 grapes. Given past experience, the store knows that they can propose a banana-haters package with 6 apples and 30 grapes and that this package will bring a profit of six euros. Similarly, they can prepare a combo package with 5 apples, 6 bananas, and 20 grapes, yielding a profit of seven euros. They know they can sell any quantity of these two packages within the availability of its stock. What quantity of each package, banana-haters packages and combo packages, should the store prepare to maximize net profit?

{ "background": "A grocery store wants to liquidate its stock by selling banana-haters packages and combo packages that contain different quantities of apples, bananas, and grapes, for different profit margins.", "constraints": [ "Number of banana-haters packages is non-negative", "Number of combo packages is non-negative", "The number of apples used in banana-haters and combo packages is less than or equal to ApplesStock", "The number of bananas used in combo packages is less than or equal to BananasStock", "The number of grapes used in banana-haters and combo packages is less than or equal to GrapesStock" ], "objective": "Maximize the profit from selling banana-haters packages and combo packages", "parameters": [ { "definition": "Initial stock of apples", "symbol": "ApplesStock", "value": 10, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Initial stock of bananas", "symbol": "BananasStock", "value": 20, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Initial stock of grapes", "symbol": "GrapesStock", "value": 80, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Number of apples in a banana-haters package", "symbol": "ApplesBHPack", "value": 6, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Number of grapes in a banana-haters package", "symbol": "GrapesBHPack", "value": 30, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Profit from a banana-haters package", "symbol": "ProfitBHPack", "value": 6, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Number of apples in a combo package", "symbol": "ApplesCombo", "value": 5, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Number of bananas in a combo package", "symbol": "BananasCombo", "value": 6, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Number of grapes in a combo package", "symbol": "GrapesCombo", "value": 20, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Profit from a combo package", "symbol": "ProfitCombo", "value": 7, "shape": [] } ] }
This is an LLM Agent for optimization problems

A bakery uses a stand-mixer and a slow bake oven to make bread and cookies. Each machine can run for at most 3000 hours per year. To bake a loaf of bread takes 1 hour in the stand mixer and 3 hours in the oven. A batch of cookies requires 0.5 hours in the mixer and 1 hour in the oven. The profit per loaf of bread is $5 and the profit per batch of cookies is $3. How should the bakery operate to maximize total profit?

{ "background": "A bakery uses a stand-mixer and a slow bake oven to make bread and cookies.", "constraints": [ "Total mixer hours for bread and cookies cannot exceed MaxHours", "Total oven hours for bread and cookies cannot exceed MaxHours", "Number of loaves of bread is non-negative", "Number of batches of cookies is non-negative" ], "objective": "Maximize the total profit from bread and cookies", "parameters": [ { "definition": "Maximum operational hours per year for the stand-mixer and the oven", "symbol": "MaxHours", "value": 3000, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Hours taken in the stand mixer to make a loaf of bread", "symbol": "BreadMixerHours", "value": 1, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Hours taken in the oven to bake a loaf of bread", "symbol": "BreadOvenHours", "value": 3, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Hours taken in the stand mixer to make a batch of cookies", "symbol": "CookieMixerHours", "value": 0.5, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Hours taken in the oven to bake a batch of cookies", "symbol": "CookieOvenHours", "value": 1, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Profit per loaf of bread", "symbol": "ProfitBread", "value": 5, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Profit per batch of cookies", "symbol": "ProfitCookies", "value": 3, "shape": [] } ] }
This is an LLM Agent for optimization problems

A glass factory makes two types of glass panes: a regular glass pane and a tempered glass pane. Both require time on a heating and cooling machine. Both machines are available for a maximum of 300 minutes per day. It takes 3 minutes in the heating machine and 5 minutes in the cooling machine to make one regular glass pane. It takes 5 minutes in the heating machine and 8 minutes in the cooling machine to make one tempered glass pane. The profit per pane of regular glass is $8 and the profit per pane of tempered glass is $10. How many panes of each glass type should the factory make to maximize profit? What is the maximum profit?

A souvenir shop makes wooden elephants and tigers with plastic ornaments. Each elephant requires 50 grams of wood and 20 grams of plastic. Each tiger requires 40 grams of wood and 30 grams of plastic. In a week, 5000 grams of wood and 4000 grams of plastic are available. The profit per elephant sold is $5 and the profit per tiger sold is $4. How many of each should be made in order to maximize profit?

An art store makes large and small art pieces. The store has available 100 units of paint, 50 units of glitter, and 70 units of glue. To make a large art piece requires 4 units of paint, 3 units of glitter, and 5 units of glue. To make a small art piece requires 2 units of paint, 1 unit of glitter, and 2 units of glue. The store must make at least 5 units of each large and small art pieces. If the profit per large art piece is $30 and the profit per small art piece is $15, how many of each should be made to maximize profit?

My family has decided to invest in real state for the first time. Currently, they have $600,000 to invest, some in apartments and the rest in townhouses. The money invested in apartments must not be greater than $200,000. They have decided that the money invested in apartments must be at least a half as much as that in townhouses. If the apartments earn 10%, and the townhouses earn 15%, how much money should they invest in each to maximize profit?

{ "background": "A family wants to invest its total budget into two types of real estate: apartments and townhouses.", "constraints": [ "Money invested in both apartments and townhouses must be non-negative", "Total investment in apartments and townhouses must not exceed TotalInvestment", "Investment in apartments must not exceed MaxApartments", "Investment in apartments must be at least MinInvestmentRatio times the investment in townhouses" ], "objective": "Maximize the total profit from investing in apartments and townhouses, with profit rates of ProfitRateApts and ProfitRateTH respectively", "parameters": [ { "definition": "Total investment amount available", "symbol": "TotalInvestment", "value": 600000, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Maximum amount that can be invested in apartments", "symbol": "MaxApartments", "value": 200000, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Minimum ratio of the money invested in apartments to that in townhouses", "symbol": "MinInvestmentRatio", "value": 0.5, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Profit rate for apartments", "symbol": "ProfitRateApts", "value": 0.1, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Profit rate for townhouses", "symbol": "ProfitRateTH", "value": 0.15, "shape": [] } ] }

My grandma is required to take two medicines Z1 and D3 everyday. She needs to take at least 5 grams of Z1 and 10 grams of D3 everyday. These medicines are available in two pills named Zodiac and Sunny. One pill of Zodiac contains 1.3 grams of Z1 while one pill of Sunny contains 1.2 grams of Z1. On the other hand, one pill of Zodiac contains 1.5 grams of D3 and one pill of Sunny contains 5 grams of D3. The cost per pill of Zodiac is $1 and the cost per pill of Sunny is $3. Formulate a LP such that the medicine requirement can be fulfilled at the lowest cost.

{ "background": "My grandma is required to take two medicines Z1 and D3 everyday. There are two types of pills available: Zodiac and Sunny, containing different quantities of Z1 and D3.", "constraints": [ "Grandma needs to take at least MinZ1 grams of Z1 everyday", "Grandma needs to take at least MinD3 grams of D3 everyday", "Number of Zodiac pills is non-negative", "Number of Sunny pills is non-negative" ], "objective": "Minimize the total cost of the pills while fulfilling the medicine requirements","parameters": [ { "definition": "Minimum required grams of medicine Z1 per day", "symbol": "MinZ1", "value": 5, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Minimum required grams of medicine D3 per day", "symbol": "MinD3", "value": 10, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Grams of Z1 in one pill of Zodiac", "symbol": "Z1perZodiac", "value": 1.3, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Grams of Z1 in one pill of Sunny", "symbol": "Z1perSunny", "value": 1.2, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Grams of D3 in one pill of Zodiac", "symbol": "D3perZodiac", "value": 1.5, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Grams of D3 in one pill of Sunny", "symbol": "D3perSunny", "value": 5, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Cost per pill of Zodiac", "symbol": "CostZodiac", "value": 1, "shape": [] }, { "definition": "Cost per pill of Sunny", "symbol": "CostSunny", "value": 3, "shape": [] } ] }

A hobbyist makes model trains and planes using wood and paint. A model train requires 3 units of wood and 3 units of paint. A model plane requires 4 units of wood and 2 units of paint. The hobbyist has available 120 units of wood and 90 units of paint. If the profit per model train is $8 and the profit per model plane is $10, how many of each should be made to maximize his profit?

An electronics store wants to optimize how many phones and laptops are enough to keep in inventory. A phone will earn the store $120 in profits, and a laptop will earn $40. A phone requires 1 sq ft of floor space, whereas a laptop requires 4 sq ft. In total, 400 sq ft of floor space is available. The store stocks only phones and laptops. Corporate has required that at least 80% of all appliances in stock be laptops. Finally, a phone costs $400 for the store, and a laptop, $100. The store wants to spend at most $6000. Formulate an LP that can be used to maximize the store's profit.

A candy store mixes regular candy and sour candy to prepare two products, regular mix and sour surprise mix. Each kilogram of the regular mix contains 0.8 kg of regular candy and 0.2 kg of sour candy. The profit per kilogram of the regular mix is $3.
